awd_titl_txt: CRII: SHF: Ultra-fast Simulation and Automated Design of Silicon Photonics Devices
awd_abstract_narration:
Integrated circuits are responsible for most of modern technology today. While electronic circuits have been sufficient for advancing technology until this point, the challenging computational, energy-efficiency, and communication demands of the 21st century require a radically new paradigm. This can be found in silicon photonics, an emerging technology which allows the manipulation of light by integrating optical devices on the same chips as electrical circuits. The ability to control light on a chip has already led to important technological advancements, including ultra-high-speed wired and wireless communications, lens-free imaging, Light Detection and Ranging (LiDAR), gyroscopes without moving parts, gas sensors, and label-free biosensors. This project seeks to solve device simulation and design difficulties which currently severely limit the potential of silicon photonics, ushering in a new generation of chips with unprecedented levels of performance and design complexity, and paving the way for on-chip optical computation and ultra-fast, efficient communication. Leveraging mathematical and computational modeling, this research will engage and train graduate and undergraduate students in multi-disciplinary fields spanning from mathematics to computer engineering and applied physics. Another objective is to engage high school students from local schools interested in STEM, with a specific focus on women and underrepresented groups. This project will spur the growth of powerful new design tools for silicon photonics which will allow human designers to maximize their efforts designing at the system level, rather than at the device level, allowing them to develop highly intricate systems.

Due to their large size, small features, and complexity, photonic devices are very challenging to numerically simulate, and the lack of analytical or even approximate solutions further complicates the design of new devices. Advanced numerical techniques based on boundary integral equation methods will be developed in this project and applied to model photonic devices. Unlike present approaches which necessitate volumetric meshing of devices to be simulated, the project's approach only requires meshing the surfaces or boundaries of devices, leading to a significant reduction of problem size and dramatic increases in speed and CPU and memory efficiency. High-order polynomial functions will be used to approximate the electromagnetic unknowns, leading to an almost exponential rate of convergence to the exact solution with respect to the mesh size, in contrast to present methods which can only achieve linear or quadratic convergence. An optimization framework will be designed and implemented which will be capable of automatically designing new, ready-to-fabricate photonic devices without any human intervention other than specification of desired functionality and performance. The efficacy of the new simulation and optimization platform will then be demonstrated by utilizing the framework to design and evaluate real silicon photonic devices such as wavelength demultiplexers, power splitters, and grating couplers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Silicon photonics is a rapidly growing field due to its potential for enabling many exciting applications, including high-speed communication links, highly sensitive biosensors, gyrometers, gas sensors, LIDAR for self-driving cars, fully-optical computation, and many more. Major advances in these areas are likely to significantly impact society as a whole-- for instance, in order for the rapidly increasding wireless communication demands to be met, we will need to rely very fast and efficient wired network backbones which can utiilize photonic-based interconnects. As another example, the most expensive sensor on a self-drivign car is currently the LIDAR system, which often costs more than the rest of the car itself. Silicon photonics can potentially replace the LIDAR system with an integrated solid-state sensor that can be orders of magnitude cheaper while delivering similar or improved performance.

This goal of this project was to design an automated design framework for silicon photonic devices, allowing the computer software to design devices which are ready to be fabricated given only the desired specifications and fabrication constraints as input from the human designer. Since there are no analytical or closed-form solutions for modeling these devices, engineers have very little physical intuition when designing them and their design can be very time intensive and cumbersome. Such an approach is known as inverse design, in which desired performance specifications are provided as inputs to a computer algorithm, which uses optimization techniques to find a suitable structure which can meet these specifications. Since optimization algorithms must evaluate the performance of candidate designs at every iteration, inverse design of nanophotonic devices crucially relies on fast and accurate electromagnetic solvers. Many of the efforts of this project therefore went towards developing new solvers which could significantly accelerate full-wave 3D Maxwell solutions of silicon photonic devices and coupling them with fast gradient-based optimization methods.

We developed and introduced the Chebyshev-based Integral Equation (CBIE) method for solving Maxwell?s equations in three dimensions, which is a very efficient Nystr?m-based approach for discretizing boundary integral equations. Boundary integral equations have the distinct advantage over other volumetric approaches, such as Finite Difference and Finite Element methods, in that they only require meshing and solving for unknowns on the surfaces between different dielectric volumes rather than inside the whole volumes. This can significantly reduce the number of unknowns required, especially for objects with large volume to surface-area ratios. Furthermore, the CBIE method achieves high-order accuracy in the solution with respect to the number of unknowns since it leverages high-order polynomials for representing the unknown field and current distributions. This further enables reduction of computational complexity and memory requirements by allowing acceptable solution accuracies to be obtained with coarse discretizations of the geometry.

We also leveraged hardware acceleration by using Graphics Processing Units (GPUs) to compute the far-interactions, which are order N2 and constitute most of the computational complexity of the solver. This resulted in up to 50x speed-ups over CPU only configurations, and we demonstrated that 3D Maxwell problems with over a million unknowns could be solved in a matter of minutes by using even consumer-grade GPUs on a personal desktop workstation.

Finally, we developed a framework which uses the adjoint-method to rapidly evaluate the gradients of an objective function with respect to the optimization parameters in the context of our CBIE solver. We demonstrated the capabilities of this platform by using it to inverse design a 1:2 nanophotonic power splitter with greater than 98% input to output efficiency at 1550nm and highly efficient mode-preserving non-adiabatic silicon photonic tapers, which at the time were the largest devices inverse designed using 3D full-wave Maxwell simulations without any approximations.

We also designed a grating coupler wavelength demultiplexer, which can couple signals centered at both 1310nm and 1550nm simultaneously from one optical fiber and split them into opposing outgoing directions on on-chip silicon waveguides. We fabricated this design using a standard silicon photonics foundry process, measured it in the lab, and showed close agreement with the results predicted by our simulations.

The results from this project have all been disseminated to the broader research community via both conference and journal publications.

We expect that our fast modeling and inverse design framework will not only save engineers significant time by designing nanophotonic devices for them, allowing them to focus on the system level aspects of their projects, but will also be able to explore far richer design parameter landscape than a human designer, leading to high-performance, non-intuitive designs that would have been impossible for a human to manually design. By enabling the rapid, efficient design of silicon photonic devices, we hope that this work will enable many of the aforementioned silicon photonics applications to become realities, resulting in a significant societal and broader impact by majorly improving connectivity.
